Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Scalable Bottom-up Synthesis of Well-defined Diamond Nanowire/Nanotube Arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grant in Engineering (BRIGE) grant provides funding to develop a novel bottom-up nanofabrication method to synthesize semiconducting diamond nanowires. Vertically aligned diamond nanowire arrays will be fabricated with well-defined nanostructures and high aspect ratios by the proposed bottom-up nanofabrication method. The processing parameters will be optimized to control the size and shape of diamond nanowires. Theoretical work will be carried out to achieve a physical understanding of the diamond crystal growth to provide more insights for the nanofabrication process. Synthesized diamond nanowires will be experimentally characterized in order to reveal their structure-property and size-property relationships. Both experimental and theoretical efforts will be implemented to achieve a simple and cost-effective technique for large-scale fabrication of well-defined diamond nanowire arrays.

If successful, this research will lead to a novel manufacturing process for diamond nanowires. The technology developed in this work will contribute to wider applications of nanodiamond in various fields, such as chemical sensors, biological assays, optoelectronics, and supercapacitors. In addition, this research will be closely integrated with educational activities to broaden participation of undergraduate and graduate students who are members of minority groups in engineering research so that they may choose an engineering career in the future. Through collaboration with a campus outreach program, the proposed interactive two-day summer workshop will provide K-12 students unique hands-on-experience opportunities on cutting-edge engineering technologies, and stimulate their interests in science and engineering. The results of this project will be integrated into curriculum and broadly disseminated through NSF annual reports, conference presentations, and journal publications.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
A facile and cost-effective template-based electrophoretic deposition method was firstly utilized to fabricate vertically aligned diamond nanowire/nanotube arrays. Material characterization results confirmed that the one-dimensional nanodiamond structures with high aspect ratio can be synthesized on a large area with controlled length and diameter by adjusting process parameters. As-synthesized diamond nanostructures demonstrated promising field emission properties with a turn-on current density about 10-fold lower than that of a diamond nanoparticle film. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the thermal conductivity properties of as-fabricated nanodiamond nanowires/nanotubes allow for the potential applications as thermal interface materials and the conductivity is tunable by choosing different electrolyte solvents. Further optimization of the diamond nanotube structure and the interface between nanotubes and substrate resulted in an improvement in the field emission properties and thermal conductivity.

The research significantly advances fundamental understanding of (a) liquid phase behaviors of nanodiamond electrolyte solutions and (b) nucleation and crystal growth of nanodiamonds in nanoscale cylindrical confinement under external electric field. The research results have been closely integrated into educational activities through the graduate student support, undergraduate student mentoring, summer outreach program, and new topics in current curriculum. As a female faculty, the PI attracts, recruits and mentors female/underrepresented students through education-related research. Two PhD students and 5 REU undergraduate students were recruited to work on this project. They gain research experiences on the cutting-edge nanotechnology through research-related learning process and solving engineering problems. The outcomes of this project have been widely disseminated through annual conference, high-quality journals, curriculum, and seminars. This approach opens a new avenue for mass-production of the vertically aligned diamond nanotube arrays for industrial applications. The proposed electrodeposition technique for diamond nanowire synthesis have a positive impact on the electrochemistry, organic chemistry, material science and engineering, photon physics, and thermal transport science.


Last Modified: 11/10/2016
Modified by: Jingjing Qiu

Material characterization results confirmed that the one-dimensional nanodiamond structures with high aspect ratio can be synthesized on a large area with controlled length and diameter by adjusting process parameters. Moreover, it was demonstrated that the thermal conductivity properties of as-fabricated nanodiamond nanowires/nanotubes allow for the potential applications as thermal interface materials and the conductivity is tunable by choosing different electrolyte solvents. Further optimization of the diamond nanotube structure and the interface between nanotubes and substrate resulted in an improvement in the field emission properties and thermal conductivity. The research significantly advances fundamental understanding of (a) liquid phase behaviors of nanodiamond electrolyte solutions and (b) nucleation and crystal growth of nanodiamonds in nanoscale cylindrical confinement under external electric field. The research results have been closely integrated into educational activities through the graduate student support, undergraduate student mentoring, summer outreach program, and new topics in current curriculum. As a female faculty, the PI attracts, recruits and mentors female/underrepresented students through education-related research. Two PhD students and 5 REU undergraduate students were recruited to work on this project. They gain research experiences on the cutting-edge nanotechnology through research-related learning process and solving engineering problems.
